title: Top 10 Amazing NEW SPECIES

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: How X-rays see through your skin - Ge Wang

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered X-rays in 1895?

options.text: They can cause mutations in reproductive organs

options.label: B
options.text: They can make images of organs without harming them

options.label: C
options.text: They have higher energy than Gamma rays

options.label: D
options.text: They are only absorbed by bones

multiple-choice.question: What happens when X-rays interact with matter?

options.label: A
options.text: They only transfer some of their energy and the rest is scattered

options.label: B
options.text: They always transfer all of their energy and get absorbed

options.label: C
options.text: They either transfer all of their energy and get absorbed or transfer some of their energy and the rest is scattered

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Why do bones absorb X-rays better than soft tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: Bones are less dense and contain lower atomic number elements

options.label: B
options.text: Bones are denser and contain higher atomic number elements

options.label: C
options.text: Bones and soft tissue absorb X-rays equally

options.label: D
options.text: Soft tissue is denser and contains higher atomic number elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of 2D X-ray pictures?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only be used for medical applications

options.label: B
options.text: They can only be used to image bones

options.label: C
options.text: They reflect the sum of all interactions along the path of the X-ray

options.label: D
options.text: They can only be used to image soft tissue

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of taking X-ray views from multiple angles around the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To construct an internal image of the body

multiple-choice.question: What is a CT (Computed Tomography) scan?

options.label: B
options.text: A medical procedure that uses X-rays to construct an internal image of the body

options.label: D
options.text: A type of medical imaging that uses magnetic fields

multiple-choice.question: How does a CT scanner work?

options.label: A
options.text: By sending a single X-ray beam through the patient

options.label: B
options.text: By sending a fan or cone of X-rays through the patient to an array of detectors

options.label: C
options.text: By using magnetic fields to image the body

options.label: D
options.text: By using radiation to destroy tumors

multiple-choice.question: What can CT scans detect?

options.label: C
options.text: Anatomical features, tumors, blood clots, infections, heart disease, and cavities

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many CT scans are conducted worldwide each year?

title: How to make a mummy - Len Bloch

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They left them in the body

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To make the body more lifelike

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the famously difficult green-eyed logic puzzle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition under which a prisoner can leave the island?

options.label: A
options.text: If they have green eyes and approach the guards at night.

options.label: B
options.text: If they have non-green eyes and approach the guards at night.

options.label: C
options.text: If they approach the guards during the day.

options.label: D
options.text: If they try to escape without asking the guards.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason the prisoners do not try to leave the island initially?

options.label: A
options.text: They are afraid of the volcano.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not allowed to communicate among themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not know their own eye color and do not want to risk failure.

options.label: D
options.text: They are happy living on the island.

multiple-choice.question: What statement do you make to the prisoners to help them escape?

options.label: A
options.text: "At least one of you has green eyes."

multiple-choice.question: How many mornings after your visit do all the prisoners leave the island?
What concept, coined by philosopher David Lewis, is key to understanding how the prisoners escape?
What is the main difference between the prisoners' knowledge before and after your statement?

options.label: A
options.text: They learn new information about their own eye color.

options.label: B
options.text: They learn new information about the eye color of the other prisoners.

options.label: C
options.text: They gain common knowledge that everyone else is keeping track of the green-eyed people they can see.

multiple-choice.question: How many days could you have spared the prisoners by telling them a different statement?
What would have happened if you had told the prisoners "At least 99 of you have green eyes"?

options.label: A
options.text: They would have left the island on the 100th morning.

options.label: B
options.text: They would have left the island on the 2nd morning.

options.label: C
options.text: They would have left the island on the 99th morning.

options.label: D
options.text: They would not have left the island.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of inductive reasoning in the prisoners' escape?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to deduce their own eye color from the statement.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to understand the concept of common knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to generalize the pattern of behavior to any number of prisoners.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to the prisoners' escape.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the dictator initially suspicious of your statement?

options.label: A
options.text: He thinks it will give the prisoners new information.

options.label: B
options.text: He thinks it will not change anything.

options.label: C
options.text: He thinks it is a trick.

options.label: B

title: How to make an attractive city

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary argument made in the manifesto about how to make attractive cities?

options.label: A
options.text: Cities should be designed with a focus on functionality and efficiency.

options.label: B
options.text: Cities should be designed with a focus on aesthetics and beauty.

options.label: C
options.text: Cities should be designed with a mix of old and new architecture.

options.label: D
options.text: Cities should be designed with a focus on sustainability and environmentalism.

multiple-choice.question: According to the manifesto, what is the ideal balance between order and variety in a city?

options.label: A
options.text: A city should have a high level of order and a low level of variety.

options.label: B
options.text: A city should have a low level of order and a high level of variety.

options.label: C
options.text: A city should have a balance between order and variety, with neither being too dominant.

options.label: D
options.text: A city should have a complete lack of order and variety.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second principle of good cities mentioned in the manifesto?

options.label: C
options.text: Cities should have a strong sense of community.

options.label: D
options.text: Cities should have a high level of technological advancement.

multiple-choice.question: According to the manifesto, what is the benefit of having a compact city?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more space for individual homes and gardens.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the need for public transportation.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the sense of community and social connection among residents.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the city's environmental impact.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ideal size for a city square, according to the manifesto?

options.label: D
options.text: The size of the square is not important.

multiple-choice.question: According to the manifesto, what is the benefit of having small streets and alleyways in a city?

options.label: A
options.text: They allow for faster and more efficient transportation.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide a sense of mystery and enclosure.

options.label: C
options.text: They increase the amount of space available for development.

options.label: D
options.text: They reduce the need for public spaces and parks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with modern cities, according to the manifesto?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too small and compact.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too focused on aesthetics and beauty.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too dominated by commercial interests and lack a sense of humanity.

multiple-choice.question: According to the manifesto, what is the ideal height for a city block?
What is the benefit of using local materials and forms in building design, according to the manifesto?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the cost of construction.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the sense of community and social connection among residents.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a unique and distinctive character to the city.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the city's environmental impact.

multiple-choice.question: According to the manifesto, what is the main obstacle to building beautiful cities?

options.label: B
options.text: Intellectual confusion around beauty and lack of political will.

options.label: D
options.text: Too much focus on aesthetics and beauty.

title: How to detect a supernova - Samantha Kuula

multiple-choice.question: How often does a supernova occur in the observable universe?

options.label: B
options.text: Every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way

options.label: A
options.text: The explosion is too bright for our telescopes

options.label: B
options.text: We need to have our best telescopes focused on the right star at precisely the right time

multiple-choice.question: What type of particles wins the "supernova race" to Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Type 1 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel, while Type 2 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 is caused by a star accumulating matter from a neighboring star, while Type 2 is caused by a star running out of nuclear fuel

options.label: C
options.text: Type 1 is more powerful than Type 2

options.label: D
options.text: Type 2 is more powerful than Type 1

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To be able to witness a supernova before its light reaches Earth

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What’s the big deal with gluten? - William D. Chey

multiple-choice.question: What is gluten composed of?

options.label: A
options.text: Two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, and a type of sugar

options.label: B
options.text: Two proteins named gliadin and glutenin

options.label: C
options.text: A type of sugar and a type of fiber

options.label: D
options.text: A type of fiber and two proteins named gliadin and glutenin

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of gluten in food?

What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease?
What is the estimated occurrence of celiac disease in the U.S. population?
How is non-celiac gluten sensitivity typically diagnosed?

options.label: C
options.text: Based on symptoms, absence of wheat allergy and celiac disease, and improvement on a gluten-free diet

multiple-choice.question: What is a possible explanation for some cases of gluten sensitivity?

options.label: B
options.text: Sensitivity to sugars found in wheat, called fructans

multiple-choice.question: What is the nocebo effect, and how might it relate to gluten sensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: The nocebo effect is when a person believes something will cause problems, and it does, and it might play a role in gluten sensitivity due to media coverage

options.label: B
options.text: The nocebo effect is when a person believes something will cause problems, but it doesn't, and it has no relation to gluten sensitivity

options.label: C

title: Will future spacecraft fit in our pockets? - Dhonam Pemba

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential advantage of using microspacecraft for space exploration?

options.text: They can carry more fuel than traditional spacecraft.

options.label: B
options.text: They can carry more people than traditional spacecraft.

options.label: C
options.text: Thousands of them can be deployed for the cost of a single space shuttle mission.

options.label: D
options.text: They are less environmentally friendly than traditional spacecraft.

multiple-choice.question: What type of instruments do microspacecraft carry to collect data about the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: Only cameras to take pictures of outer space.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophisticated electronic sensors to measure everything from temperature to cosmic rays.

options.label: C
options.text: Only instruments to study the behavior of bacteria in the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: Only instruments to study magnetic signals that could help predict earthquakes.

multiple-choice.question: Why are microspacecraft individually expendable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are very expensive to build.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can only be used once.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can be sent into environments that are too risky for a billion-dollar rocket or probe.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not useful for space exploration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in propelling microspacecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: They require a large engine to propel themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: They require tons of fuel to propel themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: They cannot carry a large engine or tons of fuel, so they need micropropulsion.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not need any propulsion system.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a micropropulsion system being developed at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory?
How does the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system work?

options.label: A
options.text: It shoots out charged particles to generate momentum using a large engine.

options.label: B
options.text: It shoots out charged particles to generate momentum using capillary action and an electric field.

options.label: C
options.text: It uses a rocket engine to generate thrust.

options.label: D
options.text: It uses solar sails to generate thrust.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the electric field in the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system?

options.label: A
options.text: It pulls the molten metal back, causing the indium to deform into a cone.

options.label: B
options.text: It tugs the molten metal upwards, while surface tension pulls it back, causing the indium to deform into a cone.

options.label: C
options.text: It generates a large amount of heat to melt the indium.

options.label: D
options.text: It generates a large amount of thrust to propel the spacecraft.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system compared to traditional rocket engines?

options.label: A
options.text: It generates more thrust than traditional rocket engines.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more fuel-efficient and better suited for long deep-space missions.

options.label: C
options.text: It is heavier than traditional rocket engines.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more expensive than traditional rocket engines.

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted outcome of using micropropulsion systems in microspacecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: They will not provide enough thrust to break small craft out of Earth's orbit.

options.label: B
options.text: They will provide enough thrust to break small craft out of Earth's orbit, but only for short missions.

options.label: C
options.text: They will provide enough thrust to break small craft out of Earth's orbit, and thousands of microspacecraft will be launched in the next ten years.

options.label: D
options.text: They will only be used for Earth-orbiting missions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of using microspacecraft for space exploration?

options.label: A
options.text: It will reduce the amount of data that can be collected about the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It will increase the cost of space exploration.

options.label: C
options.text: It will exponentially increase the amount of data that can be collected about the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: It will have no impact on space exploration.
